title: The Bride’s Desire
shortSummary: Song of Solomon Chapter 1 introduces the intimate and poetic dialogue between the bride and her beloved, expressing deep affection and longing. The chapter highlights the beauty of love, the sweetness of intimacy, and the desire for closeness within the covenant of marriage.
timeline: c. 970 BC - Reign of King Solomon, traditional period of authorship

keyCharacters.name: The Shulammite Woman
keyCharacters.description: The bride who expresses her love and longing for her beloved, describing her own appearance and feelings.

keyCharacters.name: The Beloved (Solomon)
keyCharacters.description: The bridegroom, traditionally understood as Solomon, who is praised for his beauty and love.

keyCharacters.name: Daughters of Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The female chorus or community who observe and comment on the bride’s appearance and situation.

definitions.definition: Fragrant oils or perfumes used in ancient times for anointing and enhancing beauty, symbolizing love and attraction.
Young unmarried women, often representing purity and admiration for the bridegroom.
A costly and fragrant perfume mentioned in the Bible, symbolizing preciousness and devotion.
A nomadic tribe known for their dark tents, used metaphorically to describe the bride’s complexion.

outline.heading: Introduction and Expression of Desire
outline.description: The chapter opens with the bride’s passionate desire for the kisses of her beloved, emphasizing the sweetness of love and the joy found in intimate fellowship.

outline.heading: The Bride’s Self-Description and Social Context
outline.description: The bride describes her dark complexion and the challenges she faces, highlighting themes of identity, acceptance, and longing for love despite social rejection.

outline.heading: The Bride’s Inquiry and Invitation
outline.description: She seeks to know where her beloved tends his flock, expressing a desire to be near him and participate in his daily life.

outline.heading: Praises of the Beloved’s Beauty and Gifts
outline.description: The bride extols the physical beauty and precious adornments of her beloved, using rich imagery to convey admiration and deep affection.

application: Cherish and express love within the marriage covenant as a reflection of Christ’s love for the church.
Embrace God’s design for beauty and identity, finding confidence in His acceptance despite worldly judgments.
Seek intimacy and closeness with your spouse through intentional communication and affection.
Remember that love is both a gift and a commitment, requiring devotion and rejoicing in one another.

keyVerses.text: Let him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.
keyVerses.significance: This verse captures the bride’s longing for intimate love, emphasizing the surpassing sweetness and joy of God-ordained affection.

keyVerses.text: Draw me, we will run after thee: the king hath brought me into his chambers: we will be glad and rejoice in thee, we will remember thy love more than wine: the upright love thee.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the joy and delight found in the beloved’s presence, symbolizing the spiritual and emotional fulfillment in God’s love.

keyVerses.text: Behold, thou art fair, my love; behold, thou art fair; thou hast doves' eyes.
keyVerses.significance: A tender affirmation of the beloved’s beauty and purity, encouraging believers to appreciate and affirm their spouse’s God-given qualities.
